The **Forty-Third Difficulty** states:

「Why does a person die within seven days if they neither eat nor drink?
If one does not consume food and water, how can they survive beyond seven days before death?

Yet:
The stomach always retains **two dou** of grain and **one dou five sheng** of water.
Without roots or nourishment, food and drink are essential to life.
The stomach is the **sea of water and grain**, and when it receives water and grain, it retains **three dou five sheng**.
Thus, an average person urinates **twice daily**.
The **凤** (*feng*), meaning **wind** or **urination**, is the place of discharge.
An average person urinates twice daily, removing **two sheng and half** each time.
By midday, they expel **five sheng**.
If they urinate twice more by day’s end, they remove another **two sheng and half**, totaling **five sheng** daily.
Seven days:
Within seven days.
Five times seven:
Seven sets of **five sheng**.
Thus, **three dou five sheng** of water and grain are exhausted.
Each urination removes **five sheng**, so within seven days, **three dou five sheng** of water and grain are depleted.
Therefore, an average person dies within seven days without food or drink because their **water and grain essence** (*jinye*) are all spent, and thus they die.
All cases where an average person dies after seven days without food or drink are due to the exhaustion of **water and grain essence** (*jinye*), hence death.

**The Forty-Fourth Difficulty** asks:
Where are the **Seven Orifices** (*Qichuangmen*) located?
The **orifices** (*chong*) refer to pathways of passage and discharge for the **organs and bowels** (*zangfu*).
Where are the **Seven Orifices** (*Qichuangmen*)?

Yet:
The **lips** are the **Flying Orifice** (*Feimen*).
The lips belong to the **spleen** (*pi*), and they are dynamic in motion.
It is said that the lips receive water and grain, then transform them inward.

The **teeth** are the **Gate Orifice** (*Mumen*).
The mouth and teeth are the pathways for the **heart-qi** (*xinqi*).
In the heart, they manifest as **intent** (*zhi*); when spoken, they become **words** (*yan*), hence the teeth are the **orifices of the heart**.
They also serve to **crush and subdue** the five grains, passing them inward.

The **stomach** is the **Respectful Orifice** (*Binmen*).
**Respectful** (*bin*) refers to the **steamer** (*ge*), where the stomach-qi discharges.
The stomach transmits **grain-qi** (*guqi*) to the lungs, and since the **steamer** (*ge*) is above the stomach, it is called the **Respectful Orifice**.

The **epiglottis** is the **Inhaling Orifice** (*Ximen*).
The epiglottis serves as the **orifice for the sounds of the five organs** (*zang*).

The **lower opening of the great stomach** (*Dacangxiakou*) is the **Dark Orifice** (*Youmen*).
The **great stomach** (*dacang*) refers to the stomach.
Its lower opening lies three **cun** below the **navel** (*qi*), a hidden and obscure location, hence the **Dark Orifice**.

The **junction of the large and small intestines** is the **Barrier Orifice** (*Lanmen*).
**Junction** (*hui*) means **union**.
Where the large and small intestines meet, they **separate water and grain essence from vital blood**, each returning to their proper place—hence the **Barrier Orifice**.

The **lower extreme** is the **Soul Orifice** (*Pomen*).
The **Soul Orifice** (*pomen*) refers to the **anus** (*gāng*).
Lung-qi ascends through the throat and descends through the anus—this is the pathway of lung-qi.
The lungs **house the soul** (*po*), thus it is called the **Soul Orifice**.
Hence, they are called the **Seven Orifices**.

So it is said that the **Seven Orifices** are the seven pathways of passage and discharge for the **organs and bowels**.

**The Forty-Fifth Difficulty** asks:
Why does the Classic speak of the **Eight Convergences** (*Bahui*)?
How do the **organs** (*zang*), **bowels** (*fu*), **tendons** (*jin*), **bones** (*gu*), **marrow** (*sui*), **blood** (*xue*), **vessels** (*mai*), and **qi** converge?

Yet:
The **bowels converge at the great stomach** (*Fu hui dacang*).
The **convergence** (*hui*) of the **foot field** (*zuchang*)—where the **stomach** (*wei*) and **spleen** (*pi*) meet—
the **hand greater yang** (*shoutaiyang*) **small intestine** (*xiao chang*),
the **hand lesser yang** (*shao taiyang*) **triple burner** (*san jiao*),
and the **conception vessel** (*ren mai*) meet—
is originally called the **middle courtyard** (*zhongyuan*), the **great stomach** (*dacang*), and the **suction point** (*zhuo mu*).
The stomach transforms **qi** and nourishes the six bowels, hence it is called the **convergence**.

The **organs converge at the lateral ribs** (*Zang hui jixie*).
The **lateral ribs** (*jixie*) are the **soft ribs** (*ruan xie*).
At their ends lies a **suction point** (*mu*), which belongs to the **spleen**.
The **foot lesser yin** (*zue jinyin*) and **foot lesser yang** (*zue jinyin*) converge here—
hence, it is called the **convergence of the organs at the lateral ribs**.

The **tendons converge at Yanglingquan** (*Jin hui yanglingquan*).
The **Yanglingquan** (*yanglingquan*) **suction point** lies one **cun** above the **knee** (*xiguan*), in the **popliteal fossa** (*kang*).
It is where the **qi of the foot lesser yang** (*zue shaoyang*) **gallbladder** (*dan*) **bowel** discharges.

The **marrow converges at Juegu** (*Sui hui juegu*).
**Juegu** is the name of a **bone**.
Its **suction point** lies four **cun** above the **external ankle** (*waixu*), at the **yangzhen** (*yangzhen*) **suction point**.
It is also where the **qi of the foot lesser yang** (*zue shaoyang*) **bowel** discharges.

The **blood converges at Gegu** (*Xue hui gegu*).
The **gegū** (*gegū*) **suction points** are two points on the back,
below the seventh vertebra, each one and a half **cun** from the sides.
They are where the **qi of the foot greater yang** (*zue taiyang*) **bladder** (*pangguang*) **bowel** discharges.

The **bones converge at Dayu** (*Gu hui dayu*).
The **dayu** (*dayu*) **suction point** lies beside the first vertebra at the back of the neck,
each one and a half **cun** from the sides.
It is where the **qi of the foot greater yang** (*zue taiyang*) **bowel** discharges.

The **vessels converge at Taiyuan** (*Mai hui taiyuan*).
The **Taiyuan** (*tai yuan*) **suction point** lies within one **cun** of the right **wrist** (*zhang*), at the **fish际** (*yujie*).
It is where the **qi of the hand lesser yin** (*shoutaiyin*) **lung** (*fei*) **bowel** discharges.

The **qi converges at the Triple Burner** (*San jiao*), externally along a **tendon** leading to the **two breasts** (*liang ru*).
The **upper burner** (*shang jiao*) lies below the heart, and the **middle burner** (*zhong jiao*) is above the stomach.
The **lower burner** (*xia jiao*) is below the **navel** (*qi*), one and six-tenths **cun** beneath the **玉堂** (*yutang*).
It aligns with the **two breasts’ depression** (*liang ru guan xian*), which is the **膻中** (*dan zhong*) **suction point**.

It is said that **qi** from the **丹中** (*dan zhong*)—the **ministerial messenger’s office** (*chen shi zhi guan*)—
emanates from the **sea of qi** (*qi hai*), then spreads downward to irrigate all the **organs**.
For internal **heat diseases** (*re bing*), one takes the **convergence suction points** (*hui zhi qixue*) externally.
If the **heat disease** (*re bing*) lies within, one externally targets its **convergence suction points** (*hui zhi qixue*)
to dispel the illness.

**The Forty-Sixth Difficulty** asks:
Why do the elderly lie awake while the young sleep soundly?
Why do the elderly remain **unsettled** (*bu an*) and **unable to sleep** (*bu mei*) when lying down,
while the young, though they sleep, do not awaken?
Why do the elderly and young behave oppositely?

Yet:
The Classic says that the young are **abundant in blood and qi**.
The young are vigorous in the flow of **blood and qi**.
Their **flesh and muscles are smooth**.
Their **skin and muscle tissues are supple and moist**.
Their **qi pathways are open**.
The routes for **blood and qi** are unobstructed.
The **circulation of nourishing and defensive** (*rong wei*) **qi** is regular and unerring.
The harmony of **Heaven and Earth** (*tian di*) and the interplay of **sun and moon** (*ri yue*)
—**winter** is the **dark season** of the four seasons,
and **night** is the **winter** of a day—
the **awakening and sleeping** (*mei mei*) of humans align with these cosmic rhythms.
Since the young have not yet diminished their **defensive qi** (*wei qi*), their **awakening and sleeping** match the **yin and yang** of Heaven and Earth.
Thus, they are **spiritually alert** (*jing*) during the day but **sleep soundly** at night.

The elderly have **weakened blood and qi**.
Their **flesh and muscles are dry**.
Their **qi pathways are sluggish**.」

「When the **blood and qi** pathways become **sluggish** (*se*), their **egress and ingress** fail to follow the proper **cosmic timing** (*shí*).
Thus, the elderly cannot be **spiritually alert** (*jing*) during the day and cannot **sleep soundly** at night.

By day, they cannot find **tranquility** (*ān jìng*), and by night, they cannot **rest** (*miàn*).
Hence, it is known that the elderly cannot **sleep soundly**.

When **defensive qi** (*wei qi*) **emerges**, they **awaken**; when it **retires**, they **sleep**.
But since the **defensive qi** of the elderly has **waned** (*shuāi*), they cannot **sleep soundly** at night.

**Question Forty-Seven:** Why is it that only the human face can endure cold?

The head and face alone can withstand cold—how so?

**Explanation:** The head is the convergence of all the **Yang** pathways. *(See the diagram: "The Head as the Convergence of All Yang Pathways.")*

All the **Yin** vessels ascend only to the neck and chest before descending. The **Hand Minor Yin** (Heart channel) originates from the heart’s pericardial region beside the throat, ascends to the lungs, emerges beneath the armpit, and descends along the inner posterior aspect of the upper arm. The **Foot Minor Yin** (Kidney channel) rises from the kidneys, pierces the liver and diaphragm, enters the lungs, follows the throat, interconnects with the heart, and converges in the chest. The **Hand Major Yin** (Lung channel) originates from the lungs, emerges beneath the armpit, and descends along the inner upper arm. The **Foot Major Yin** (Spleen channel) ascends from the stomach through the diaphragm and converges in the heart. The **Hand Jueyin** (Pericardium channel) courses through the chest, emerges at the ribs, descends three *cun* below the armpit, and follows the inner upper arm. The **Foot Jueyin** (Liver channel) ascends through the diaphragm, spreads across the ribs, and follows the posterior throat.

Only the **Yang** pathways ascend to the head and ears. The **Yin** pathways do not reach the head—only the **Yang** pathways do. Thus, the face can endure cold.

Since **Yang qi** resides in the head and face, it can withstand cold.

**Question Forty-Eight:**

There are three kinds of **emptiness** and **fullness** in a person—how so?

There are three kinds of emptiness and three kinds of fullness in a person. Thus:

There is the **emptiness and fullness of the pulse**. The pulse has emptiness and fullness.
There is the **emptiness and fullness of the disease**. Disease has emptiness and fullness.
There is the **emptiness and fullness of diagnosis**. Diagnosis has emptiness and fullness.

The **emptiness and fullness of the pulse**:
A **soft** pulse is **emptiness**; a **tight and firm** pulse is **fullness**.
A soft pulse is **Yin emptiness**, hence called **emptiness**; a tight and firm pulse is **Yang fullness**, hence called **fullness**.

The **emptiness and fullness of disease**:
There are three kinds.
**Outward manifestations** are **emptiness**; **inward manifestations** are **fullness**.
First, **Yin and Yang** govern the **inner and outer**—now if **Yang is insufficient**, **Yin** surges outward to dominate, hence **outward** is **emptiness**. If **Yin is insufficient**, **Yang** invades inward to dominate, and **Yang** prevails externally, hence **inward** is **fullness**.
**Speech** is **emptiness**; **silence** is **fullness**.
Second, the **lungs govern voice**; when **voice enters the heart**, it is **speech**, hence **emptiness**. The **liver governs planning**; when it enters the heart, there is **no speech**, hence **silence** is **fullness**.
**Sluggishness** is **emptiness**; **urgency** is **fullness**.
Third, **Yang governs emptiness**, and **Yang** is **urgent**; **tight and tense skin** is **fullness**. **Yin governs stillness**, and **Yin** is **sluggish**; **loose and relaxed skin** is **emptiness**.

The **emptiness and fullness of diagnosis**:
There are four kinds.
A **soft** pulse is **emptiness**; a **firm** pulse is **fullness**.
That is, **soft and relaxed skin** is **emptiness**; **tight and strong skin** is **fullness**.
**Itching** is **emptiness**; **pain** is **fullness**.
Second, **general itching** is **emptiness**; **localized pain** is **fullness**.
**External pain with internal relief** is **external fullness and internal emptiness**.
Third, if **light pressure causes pain**, it is **external fullness**—the disease is shallow. If **heavy pressure brings relief**, it is **internal emptiness**—the disease is deep.
**Internal pain with external relief** is **internal fullness and external emptiness**.
Fourth, if **heavy pressure causes pain**, it is **internal fullness**—the disease is deep. If **light pressure brings relief**, it is **external emptiness**—the disease is shallow.

Thus it is said: **emptiness and fullness**.

**The Forty-Nine Difficulties:**

There are diseases arising from the **True Channels** themselves.
When the **True Channels** are **empty**, the **remaining tendons** slacken.
When the **victorious tendons** slacken, the ailment **emanates internally** and does not originate externally.

There are diseases caused by **external pathogens** invading the **True Channels**.
The **Five Phases** counter one another—**evil** enters from without.
How may they be distinguished? How are these two cases differentiated?

It is said:
**Worry, grief, and overthinking** injure the **Heart**.
The **Heart** governs **spirit**—the sovereign of the **Five Viscera**, the source of **cleverness** and **intuitive wisdom**.
Excessive **grief and labor** weaken the **Heart**, and when the **Heart** is injured, the **spirit** grows feeble.

**Cold exposure and excessive drinking** injure the **Lungs**.
The **Lungs** govern **skin and fur**—when the body is cold, the **skin and fur** are chilled.
They also receive **fluids and grains**; excessive drinking harms them, and the **Lungs** detest cold, hence it is said they are injured.

**Anger and rebellious *qi*** injure the **Liver**.
The **Liver** governs **planning and foresight**; the **Gallbladder** governs **courage and decisiveness**.
Though anger stems from **will**, if it is excessive, injury may occur.

**Overindulgence in food and exhaustion** injure the **Spleen**.
Doubling one’s usual intake harms the **intestines and stomach**.
When food is consumed to excess, the **stomach’s *qi*** becomes full, and the **Spleen’s vessels** are often strained.
Or, from **riding swiftly, leaping, or excessive sexual activity**, the **Spleen** may also be injured.

**Prolonged sitting in damp places or excessive exertion in water** injures the **Kidneys**.
The **loins** are the **Kidneys’ domain**; prolonged sitting obstructs the **Kidney *qi*** from flowing freely, hence damage occurs.
The **Kidney’s acupuncture point** lies at the **sole of the foot**, named **Yǒngquán (Surging Spring)**.
Residing in damp places also causes harm.
**Excessive exertion** refers to lifting heavy objects or drawing a bow;
**Entering water** refers to crossing water and falling, or **breathing difficulties** arising from the **Kidneys**, or a woman whose **menstrual flow has not ceased** yet engaging in intercourse.
These are diseases arising from the **True Channels** themselves.

The **Lungs** govern **skin and fur**, detest cold—if **Cold** injures in **Winter**, **Spring** brings **warm diseases**.

*Conglomeration* refers to *yang qi*. When *yang qi* gathers, it forms conglomeration.

Thus, *yin* is deep and latent. *Yin* by nature is still, often submerged and hidden within.

*Yang* is superficial and dynamic. *Yang* by nature is active, floating and manifesting above.

Where *qi* accumulates, it is called *accumulation*. Where *qi* gathers, it is called *conglomeration*.

They have defined upper and lower limits. The heart’s region extends upward to the navel, the kidneys downward to the navel—each has its defined limits.

They have defined left and right boundaries. The left flank and right flank each have their own defined regions.

*Conglomeration* refers to *yang qi*. The six *fǔ* (hollow organs) belong to *yang*, and the five conglomerations are formed by *yang qi*.

Their onset has no root. When the illness begins, there is no fixed origin.

They do not linger above or below. The *qi* that gathers shifts unpredictably, never remaining fixed above or below the navel.

Their pain has no fixed location—this is called *conglomeration*. The ache is not confined to a single region, hence it is called *conglomeration*.

Thus, we distinguish between *accumulation* and *conglomeration* based on whether they originate from the *zàng* or *fǔ*.

**The Fourteenth Poem on the *Five Discharges* (五泄) and Cold Damage (伤寒):**

**Difficulty 57:** How many kinds of *discharge* (泄) are there?
*Discharge* (泄) means diarrhea (利), but how many varieties exist?
Do they all have names?
Do they each have distinct designations?

Indeed: there are five kinds of *discharge* (泄), each with a different name.
The five varieties of diarrhea (泄利) differ in their *patterns* (令).
There is **stomach discharge** (胃泄), where the stomach meridian (胃经) causes diarrhea.
There is **spleen discharge** (脾泄), where the spleen meridian (脾经) causes diarrhea.
There is **large intestine discharge** (大肠泄), where the large intestine causes diarrhea.
There is **small intestine discharge** (小肠泄), where the small intestine causes diarrhea.
There is **large syndrome discharge** (大症泄), also called **posterior heaviness** (后重).
*痕* (痕) means *congestion* (结). When the lower abdomen (小腹) is congested (有结) but still desires diarrhea (而欲下利), this is **posterior heaviness** (后重), which is why it is named **kidney discharge** (肾泄).

**Stomach discharge** (胃泄) manifests as undigested food passing (饮食不化).
Wind enters the intestines (风入於肠), and earth *qi* (土#1) is obstructed in the stomach (土#1需於胃).
Thus, the stomach expels unprocessed food (泄所食之物), which exits prematurely and remains undigested (先出而不消化).
The stool is yellow in color (色黄).
The spleen governs earth (土), so diarrhea from spleen *qi* imbalance manifests as yellow stool (脾属土，泄利色黄).

**Spleen discharge** (脾泄) causes abdominal distension and fullness (腹胀满).
Excessive rain and dampness (雨淫腹疾) harm the spleen, and the spleen’s earth *qi* (脾土) is adversely affected by dampness (恶湿).
When dampness and spleen *qi* overpower each other (二气之胜), the abdomen swells and distends (故腹肚膨胀充满).
This results in **unregulated diarrhea** (泄注#2).
*注* (注) means without control (无节度).
Excess dampness causes **leaky diarrhea** (濡泻), as damp *qi* attacks the spleen internally (湿气内攻於脾).
This disrupts the separation of fluids and grains (水谷不分), leading to uncontrolled diarrhea (故泄利无度).
Eating triggers vomiting and belching (食即呕吐瞇).
The spleen and stomach are the *zàng-fǔ* (藏府) for digestion.
When the spleen is diseased, it cannot transform fluids and grains (化水谷), so eating causes vomiting and belching (故食则呕吐).

**Large intestine discharge** (大肠泄) manifests as **urgent postprandial diarrhea** (食已窘迫).
*窘迫* (窘迫) means **urgency** (急).
When the large intestine’s *qi* is deficient (大肠气虚), eating completes (食讫) but triggers **urgent wind-like expulsion** (昏凤#3), causing uncontrollable bowel movements (迫急不可止).
The stool is white in color (大便色白), derived from the lung’s white hue (白从肺色).
The intestines rumble with sharp pain (肠呜切痛), as if cut by a knife (肠内虚呜，如刀切其肠之痛).

**Small intestine discharge** (小肠泄) presents as **rumbling followed by purulent bloody stool** (搜而便脓血).
The small intestine is the *fǔ* (府) of the heart (心之府).
The heart generates blood (心生血), so this discharge involves bloody stool (故便血).
Pain is felt in the lower abdomen (小腹痛), where urination occurs (小便处).

**Large syndrome discharge** (大底泄) manifests as **abdominal wrapping pain and posterior heaviness** (裹急后重).
*裹急* (裹急) means **abdominal pain** (腹中痛).
*后重* (后重) means **pain at defecation** (大便处疼痛).
The patient frequently urges to defecate (数至图) but cannot (而不能便).
*囿* (囿) means **toilet** (厕).
The kidney opens into the **two yin orifices** (二阴), but when *qi* is deficient (惟气虚), the urge arises (故数思凤).
Upon reaching the toilet (及至厕), posterior heaviness prevents defecation (后重不能便).
Pain extends into the penis (茎中痛), drawing into the anterior yin orifice (前阴).

This is the **law of the Five Discharges** (五泄之法).
This is the **pathomechanism of the Five Discharges diseases** (五泄受病法度).

Indeed: there are five kinds of cold damage (伤寒).

There is **wind damage** (中风).
When struck by wind *qi* (风邪), it is called **wind damage** (中风).

There is **cold damage** (伤寒).
In winter (冬), it is called **cold damage** (伤寒).
During times of severe cold (诸严寒之时), if one is exposed to cold (为寒所冒) and falls ill (其之时而病),

thus earning the name **Five Cold Damages** (五#5伤寒).

There is **damp-warm damage** (湿温#6).
If a person has previously suffered dampness (其人尝伤於湿),
and then contracts wind (因而中风),

In spring and summer (春夏月#9), when cold is clear,

then throughout the year (一岁之中),

This is the **epidemic *qi*** (时行之气),
commonly called **Great Epidemic** (大#10行).
Each variety causes distinct suffering (其所苦各不同).
The symptoms and afflictions differ accordingly (其证候所苦害不同).

The pulse of **stroke** (*zhòngfēng*) is characterized by a floating and slippery *yang* pulse, while the *yin* pulse is damp and weak. On the surface of the muscles, where the *yang* pulse travels, a light touch reveals a pulse that seems excessive. Beneath the muscles, where the *yin* pulse travels, pressing yields a deficiency—this is called weakness. Thus, when pressing yields deficiency but lifting reveals excess, one knows it is **stroke**.

The pulse of **damp-warm illness** (*shīwēn*) is damp and weak in *yang*, while the *yin* pulse is small and tense. On the surface of the muscles, where the *yang* pulse travels, dampness and weakness indicate that damp *qi* overcomes fire. Beneath the muscles, where the *yin* pulse travels, smallness and tension signify that earthly dampness cannot overcome wood.

The pulse of **cold damage** (*shānghán*) is marked by both *yin* and *yang* pulses being excessively full and tense. The *cùn* and *chǐ* pulses are both at their peak, tense and rough.

The pulse of **heat illness** (*rèbìng*) is floating in both *yin* and *yang*. The pulse of heat illness, whether at the *cùn* or *chǐ*, is floating. When floating and slippery—light pressure reveals slipperiness—this indicates that the heart is injured by heat *qi*. When pressed deeply and dispersed with roughness—heavy pressure reveals dispersion and roughness—this indicates depletion of body fluids.

The pulse of **warm illness** (*wēnbìng*) travels through all the channels, and it is unclear which channel is affected. One must follow each channel’s symptoms to diagnose it. Warm illness arises from **epidemic *qi*** (*guǐlì zhīqì*) dispersing through the channels unpredictably; it cannot be foreseen which channel is affected. Only by observing the symptoms and diagnosing accordingly can one determine the appropriate treatment.

In **cold damage**, there are cases where sweating leads to recovery, while purgation leads to death, and cases where sweating leads to death, while purgation leads to recovery. Why is this so?

When *yang* is deficient and *yin* is excessive, sweating leads to recovery, but purgation leads to death. *Yang* deficiency causes external cold, while *yin* excess also causes external cold. Cold toxins contend within the *róngwèi*, causing alternating fever and aversion to cold. The *cùn* and *chǐ* pulses are both large and floating, yet internally, there is no restlessness. If there is slight agitation, the patient prefers warm food but dislikes cold. This indicates *yang* deficiency and *yin* excess—sweating will heal, but mistaken purgation will kill.

When *yang* is excessive and *yin* is deficient, sweating leads to death, but purgation leads to recovery. *Yang* excess causes internal heat, while *yin* deficiency also causes internal heat. Cold toxins clash within the *róngwèi*, with *yang* excess and *yin* decline. Extreme *yin* transforms into *yang*, cold begets heat, and the heat *qi* surges inward, poisoning the stomach. Body fluids dry up, and dry feces accumulate. The patient does not dislike cold externally but instead feels a steaming, dry fever, and in severe cases, delirium. Purgation will heal, but mistaken sweating will kill.

How does one diagnose **cold-heat illnesses**?

If the **skin** is affected by cold and heat: The lungs govern the skin and hair, and the large intestine is its paired organ. If the *zàng* (solid organ) is diseased, it manifests as cold; if the *fǔ* (hollow organ) is diseased, it manifests as heat. The skin cannot tolerate proximity to warmth. The hands’ three *yin* and three *yang* channels follow the movements of heaven—when heaven is active, disease arises, and the patient avoids warmth. If the hair is scorched and the nose is withered, this indicates internal heart fire causing dry heat. **Do not induce sweating**—if you do, death will follow. Purgation will heal.

If the **muscles** are affected by cold and heat: The spleen governs the muscles, and the stomach is its paired organ. Disease in the *zàng* manifests as cold, while disease in the *fǔ* manifests as heat. The skin and muscles ache. The spleen governs earth, which governs dampness, and dampness flows into the joints, causing pain. The lips and tongue wither. The spleen’s essence resides in the four whites of the lips; when its fluids leak outward, they wither. There is no sweating. This disease arises from dry dampness—**do not induce sweating**, as it will obstruct the intestines and stomach. Purgation will cause diarrhea; instead, warm the center and regulate the *qi*.

If the **bones** are affected by cold and heat: The kidneys govern the bones, and the bladder is its paired organ. If the disease is in *yang*, the body is hot, with heavy aversion to cold; if in *yin*, it is cold. The patient finds no comfort in any position.

In the *Five Thousand Nine Difficulties* (五十九难), it is asked: How does one distinguish between *madness* (狂) and *epilepsy* (癫)?

Madness and epilepsy are inherently two distinct afflictions—how does one differentiate them? Yet:

At the onset of madness (狂之始发), it is marked by excess *yang* (重阳). Madness arises when *yang* is excessive, manifesting when the disease is in the three *yang* channels and sweat is induced inappropriately—*yang* overabundance gives rise to madness. The patient does not hunger externally (少外不饥)—they have no desire for food or nourishment from the outside world. They do not wish to sleep externally (不欲眠外)—they remain unaware of hunger or fatigue. Yet they claim their own virtue and wisdom (而自高贤也, 自辩智也)—delusively boasting of their greatness and intelligence, though their actions betray no true clarity. They act haughty and disdainful (自贵倨也)—arrogantly asserting their superiority, indulging in pride, and resenting others. At the onset of epilepsy (癫疾始发), *癫* (epilepsy) is a form of *preten* (颠, vertigo). It begins when *yin* is excessive (重阴者). The patient’s mind is discontented (意不乐)—their spirit finds no peace.

The *Sixiù Nán* (六十难) states: *"Head and heart diseases"*—there are *jué* headaches (厥痛), true headaches (真痛), *jué* heart pains (厥心痛), and true heart pains (真心痛). What does this mean?

*Jué* (厥) is *líng* (玲, a sudden onset of disorder). When the three *yang* pulses of the hand (手三阳之脉) are affected by wind and cold, they stagnate and fail to flow, this is called *jué* headache. The disruptive *líng* (playing, disorderly) *qi* of wind invades the three *yang* channels, stagnates, and fails to flow, causing obstruction and a sudden surge into the head—thus it is called *jué* headache.

If the disorder follows the *lián* (连) channel into the brain (脑), it is called true headache. The brain is the *suǐhǎi* (髓海, marrow sea), and when wind and *líng* *qi* enter the *níjiǔ guān* (泥九官, muddy nine orifices), it means the *xie* (邪, pathogenic) *qi* follows the *fēngfǔ* (风府) channel into the brain, causing severe pain. When *líng* (playing) reaches the elbows and knees of the hands and feet (手足玲至肘膝), this also results in true headache.

When the *qi* of the five *zàng* (藏, viscera) interacts with one another, it is called *jué* heart pain. All channels belong to the heart (心), and if one channel is diseased, its *qi* flows in reverse, and when it reverses, it assaults the heart, causing heart pain—hence it is called *jué* heart pain. This is when the *qi* of the five *zàng* surges in reverse, causing pain, not the heart itself generating pain. When the pain is severe and the hands and feet turn blue (手足青), it is called true heart pain.

True heart pain is said to strike once in the morning and kill by evening, or strike in the evening and kill by morning. See further in the *Shíliù Nán* (十六难).

**Divine Insight and Skillful Mastery (神圣工巧, Shénshèng Gōngqiǎo) – Difficulty #16**

Now, *"to know by looking"* means observing the patient’s five colors (五色, *wǔsè*) to discern their illness. If one sees green (青色, *qīngsè*), it indicates a liver disorder (肝病, *gānbìng*); if one sees red (赤色, *chìsè*), it suggests the heart (心, *xīn*) has overpowered the liver, yet the liver is still afflicted. Thus, by observing the five colors, one may know the disease.

*"To know by hearing"* means listening to the patient’s five tones (五音, *wǔyīn*)—*guān, shāng, jiǎo, zhǐng, yǔ*—to distinguish their ailment. These five tones correspond to the five *Zàng* (藏, visceral organs). If a patient frequently weeps (好哭, *hàokū*), it is a sign of lung disease (肺病, *fèibìng*); if they enjoy singing (好歌, *hàogē*), it suggests spleen disorder (脾病, *píbìng*).

*"To know by questioning"* means inquiring about the patient’s cravings for the five flavors (五味, *wǔwèi*) to determine the source and location of their illness. When asked, a patient who prefers spicy (辛, *xīn*) flavors likely suffers from lung disease; one who favors sour (酸, *suān*) flavors, liver disease; one who craves sweet (甜, *tián*), spleen disease; one who prefers bitter (苦, *kǔ*), heart disease; and one who favors salty (咸, *xián*), kidney disease (肾病, *shènbìng*). Those who consume cold, raw foods (玲物, *língwù*) often have internal heat (内热, *nèirè*).

*"To know by pulse-taking"* means diagnosing by examining the *cùnkǒu* (寸口, radial pulse) and observing its *xūshí* (虚实, emptiness/fullness) to determine the illness and which *Zàng* (藏) or *Fǔ* (腑, hollow organs) it affects. If the pulse is *túnxī* (豚息, slack and faint) or *xián* (弦, taut), it indicates liver disorder (肝, *gān*). If a light touch reveals a slack or taut pulse, the illness lies in the hollow organs (府, *fǔ*). If a firm touch makes the pulse taut and the patient’s voice sounds hollow, the illness is in the visceral organs (藏, *zàng*). This is the meaning of *"to know by pulse-taking."*

The Classics say *"to know from outward signs"* is called *sagacity* (圣, *Shèng*). Observing the pulse (视脉, *shìmài*), initial pulse (初脉, *chūmài*), and pulse-taking (切脉, *qiēmài*) all involve knowing the illness from outward signs. *"To know from inward signs"* is called *divine insight* (神, *Shén*). This is its meaning: to perceive the illness in the mind (於心, *yúxīn*) is inward knowledge, hence called *divine insight*.

**Difficulty #61 (六十一难, *Liùshíyī Nán*) – The Five and Six (藏井荣有五，腑独有六, *Zàng Jǐng Róng Yǒu Wǔ, Fǔ Dú Yǒu Liù*)**
The *Sixiùyī Nán* (六十一难) asks: *"The visceral organs have five *jǐng* (井, wells) and five *róng* (荣, branches), while the hollow organs have six—why is this?"*

The five *Zàng* (藏) share five categories: *jǐng* (井, wells), *yù* (俞, streams), *róng* (荣, branches), *jīng* (经, channels), and *hé* (合, junctions). The six hollow organs (六府, *Liùfǔ*), however, have these five categories in addition to another point called *yuán* (原, source). How is this?

Now, the hollow organs (府, *Fǔ*) are of *Yáng* (阳, Yang) nature. The six hollow organs belong to *Yáng*. The *Sānjiāo* (三焦, Triple Burner) traverses all *Yáng* pathways, hence it is assigned a *yù* (俞) point named *yuán* (原). The *Sānjiāo* (三焦) is a ministerial organ (臣使之官, *chénshǐzhīguān*) aligned with the *Xiānghuǒ* (相火, Ministerial Fire), which carries out the commands of the *Jūnhuǒ* (君火, Sovereign Fire) across all *Yáng* channels (经, *jīng*). Thus, it is assigned a *yù* point named *yuán*.

*Yuán* (原) means *origin* (元, *yuán*). The six hollow organs share one *qi* (气) with the *Sānjiāo*, all being *Yáng* in nature, hence they are said to share one *qi*.

**Difficulty #62 (六十二难, *Liùshíèr Nán*) – The Ten Transformations (十变, *Shí Biàn*)**
The *Shí Biàn* (十变) states: *"The visceral organs, hollow organs, branches, and junctions all begin with the wells (井, *jǐng*)—why is this?"*

The five *Zàng* (藏) and six hollow organs (六府, *Liùfǔ*), with their wells (井, *jǐng*), branches (荣, *róng*), streams (俞, *yù*), channels (经, *jīng*), and junctions (合, *hé*), all trace their origins to the wells. Why is this?

Now, the wells (井, *jǐng*) represent the *east* (东方, *Dōngfāng*) and *spring* (春, *chūn*). Spring is *rén* (仁, benevolence), the greatest of the five *Cáng* (常, constants). In the yearly cycle, spring is the beginning (首, *shǒu*); in the monthly cycle, the *jiǎ* (甲) stem is the beginning. In the channel pathways, the wells are the beginning. All things are born in spring: plants sprout, insects stir, and creatures awaken. Thus, the *qíchóng* (岐虫, forked insects) move, and the *chuǎnchóng* (喘虫, panting insects) breathe. The *miánchóng* (绢虫, silkworm-like insects) and *rúchóng* (蠕虫, wriggling insects) also begin their activity in spring.

All living things that should be born arise from spring *qi* (气). Hence, the yearly count begins with spring: the first month (正月, *Zhèngyuè*) is the start of the year, so spring holds the beginning of the year. The monthly count begins with *jiǎ* (甲). The east belongs to *jiǎ* and *yǐ* (乙), both wood stems (木, *mù*), and the first month is associated with *jiǎ* and *yǐ*, both belonging to spring. Thus, the start of the twelve months lies in *jiǎ*. Therefore, the wells are the origin.

Only because of the year and month does one know that the wells are the beginning.

**Difficulty #63 (六十三难, *Liùshísān Nán*) – Yin and Yang Wells (阴井木，阳井金, *Yīn Jǐng Mù, Yáng Jǐng Jīn*)**
The *Shí Biàn* (十变) states: *"Yin wells are wood (木), Yang wells are metal (金)."*

The wells (井, *jǐng*) are like mountain valleys (谷井, *gǔjǐng*), not man-made pits. They are the places where water first emerges from the earth in mountain valleys. The same wells (井) are wood (木) in *Yáng* (阳) and metal (金) in *Yīn* (阴).

Yin branches (荣, *róng*) are fire (火), Yang branches are water (水). After water emerges from the wells, it lingers near the surface, and before it forms a great flow (大流, *dàliú*), it is called branches (荣). The branches (荣) are the state of small waters (小水, *xiǎoshuǐ*). The same branches (荣) are water (水) in *Yáng* (阳) and fire (火) in *Yīn* (阴).

Yin streams (俞, *yù*) are earth (土), Yang streams are wood (木). When the water lingers deeply, it reaches points where it can be directed to nourish the body, and these are called streams (俞). The same streams (俞) are earth (土) in *Yīn* (阴) and wood (木) in *Yáng* (阳).

Yin channels (经, *jīng*) are metal (金), Yang channels are fire (火). The channels (经) are pathways (径, *jìng*), the meaning of *jīngyíng* (经营, circulation and nourishment). As water accumulates and flows, it forms these channels. The same channels (经) are metal (金) in *Yīn* (阴) and fire (火) in *Yáng* (阳).

Yin junctions (合, *hé*) are water (水), Yang junctions are earth (土). The junctions (合) are convergences (会, *huì*), where lingering water reaches points that direct it to nourish the body. The same junctions (合) are water (水) in *Yīn* (阴) and earth (土) in *Yáng* (阳).

Why do *Yīn* (阴) and *Yáng* (阳) differ so greatly? The meaning is as follows:

This concerns the principles of *jiāng* (刚, firmness) and *róu* (柔, softness). The five *Zàng* (藏) are *Yīn* (阴) and *róu* (柔), while the six hollow organs (六府, *Liùfǔ*) are *Yáng* (阳) and *tiáo* (调, harmonious). *Yáng* alone cannot generate, nor can *Yīn* alone flourish; only when *Yáng* and *Yīn* interact as husband and wife (夫妇, *fūfù*) do they complete each other.

**On Needling Techniques: Supplementation and Drainage (第十二#52)**

The *Lùshíliùshíjiǔ Nán* (六十九难) states:
The Classics say: *"Supplement the deficient."* For deficient or weak *zàng* (藏) and *fǔ* (府), supplementation is used.
*"Drain the replete."* For overfilled or excessive *zàng* (藏) and *fǔ* (府), drainage is applied.
*"If neither deficient nor replete, follow the channel."* When none of the *zàng* (藏) are overacting and there is no imbalance of deficiency or excess, one should merely follow the channel’s sequence in applying supplementation or drainage.

Why so? How does this work?

Thus:
For the deficient, supplement the **mother**.
In spring, if the Kidney pulse is deficient, it indicates Kidney deficiency unable to transmit *qi* to the Liver.
Thus, the Kidney is supplemented—since the Kidney is the mother of the Liver, it is said, *"Supplement the mother."*

For the replete, drain the **child**.
In spring, if the Heart pulse is replete, it indicates excessive Heart-*qi* overacting upon the Liver.
Thus, the Heart is drained—since the Heart is the child of the Liver, it is said, *"Drain the child."*

First, supplementation should be applied, then drainage.

The **mother** can make the **child** replete—thus, supplementing the **mother** must come first.
The **child** can make the **mother** deficient—thus, draining the **child** must come later.

When neither replete nor deficient, one takes from the **channel itself**—this means the **channel’s own pathology** arises, not an external evil. Thus, one must take from the **channel itself**, hence the saying, *"take from the channel."*

When neither replete nor deficient, the **zàng** do not overact upon one another.

In spring, if the pulse is **tight** or merely **tight**, this is the **Liver zàng’s** own disease, and supplementation or drainage is applied to the **Foot Jueyin-Less Yang channels**.

The **channel’s own** Wood, Fire, Water, Metal, and Earth are taken according to the season.

The **70th Difficulty** says:

In autumn and winter, **yang-qi** is below, and human **qi** is also below—thus, one must take deeply.
Autumn-**qi** is in the **flesh**, winter-**qi** in the **sinews and bones**—both **yang-qi** and human **qi** are below, so the needle is used to puncture the deep **flesh**, **sinews**, and **bones**.

Spring and summer are **yang**—*cultivate* means *reach* or *attain*. In spring and summer, one cultivates **yang** by attaining one **yin** to nourish it, lest it become **lonely yang**.

In autumn and winter, **one must cultivate one yang**.
Autumn and winter are **yin**—in autumn and winter, one cultivates **yin** by attaining one **yang** to nourish it, lest it become **lonely yin**.

What does this mean? How do the four seasons’ cultivations differ?

**Chapter 78: On the Difficulties of Needling**

Needling has methods of **supplementation** and **drainage**. In **supplementation**, one exhales as the needle is withdrawn; in **drainage**, one inhales as the needle is inserted. What does this mean? How are these methods explained?

Indeed: the methods of **supplementation** and **drainage** do not strictly require exhaling or inhaling to withdraw or insert the needle. The true methods of **supplementation** and **drainage** are not concealed in the breath’s withdrawal or insertion, but rather rely on the **arrival of *qi*** as the needle enters or exits.

For those who know needling: they trust their **left hand**. When applying needling techniques, they begin with the **left hand**. For those who do not know needling: they trust their **right hand**. When ignorant of needling methods, they begin with the **right hand**. At the moment of insertion:

Before needling, one must first press and stabilize the **acupuncture point** with the **left hand**. Knowing the location of the **acupuncture point**, one presses it firmly with the **left hand**. Then, one **flicks and strains** it—with the **right hand**, one flicks the pressed point, causing the **skin’s *qi*** to swell beneath. One **hooks and lowers** the needle—**hooks and lowers** it, aligning the needle’s position. When the *qi* arrives, it appears like the **pulsing of a vein**. The *qi* arrives beneath the **left hand’s** pressure, manifesting like the **pulsing of skin** (*fǔ*). Following this, one needles along the needle’s path. Upon **arrival of *qi***, one then **pushes and inserts** the needle deeper into the **meridian**. This is called **supplementation**.

If one **flicks and lifts** it, this is called **drainage**. When *qi* arrives, one **shakes and withdraws** the needle, and this is **drainage**. If *qi* does not arrive:

If the needle is left in place for a long time and *qi* still does not come, one waits in the **Wei** layer for the *qi* to arrive; if it still does not come, one inserts deeper into the **meridian** (*Hóng*) and waits again. If, after probing these three levels—**Wei**, **meridian**, and **meridian** (*Hóng*)—the *qi* fails to respond beneath the needle, this signifies that the **Yin and Yang** have both been exhausted, and further needling is impossible. This is the case of **"male external, female internal"**—if *qi* does not arrive, it is called **"ten deaths, one survival"**.

The **Wei** layer governs **Yang**, overseeing the **external**; in males, **Yang *qi*** circulates externally, so one uses a **light touch** to press the point. The **meridian** (*Hóng*) governs **blood**, overseeing the **internal**; in females, **Yin *qi*** circulates internally, so one uses a **heavy touch** to press the point. If *qi* does not arrive even after the proper timing, and the **left hand** fails to sense it, then needling is impossible, resulting in **"ten deaths, one survival"**.

**Chapter 79: On the Difficulties of Needling**

The **classics** state: *"迎而夺之"*—how can this not result in **emptiness**? When the *qi* is just about to arrive and one uses the needle to take it, this is called *"迎而夺之"*. **迎 (Yíng)** means to **take the *qi***; **夺 (Duó)** means to **drain the *qi***. How can taking and draining it not result in **emptiness**?

The **classics** also state: *"随而济之"*—how can this not result in **fullness**? **随 (Suí)** means to **follow the *qi*** from the **Wei** layer and **supplement** it. **济 (Jì)** means to **reinforce the deficient meridian**. How can following and reinforcing it not result in **fullness**? When the *qi* flows and settles, one inserts the needle; once the needle is withdrawn, one **palpates the point**—this is called *"随而济之"*.

**Emptiness** and **fullness** are matters of **arrival or failure**. If the meridian is **weak**, yet one needles to **supplement its fullness**, the result is either **arrival or failure**—this is the critical point. If the meridian is **strong**, yet one needles to **drain its emptiness**, the result is either **arrival or failure**—this is also the critical point.

What does this mean? How are these methods explained?

Thus:

When **welcoming and taking**—this is **draining its child**. If the five **zàng** are **full**, drain their child. When **following and supplementing**—this is **reinforcing its mother**. If the five **zàng** are **empty**, supplement their mother.

Take, for instance, a **heart** disease. Using the **heart** as an example for one **zàng**:
Drain the **Shou Xin Zhu** (Palace) point. The **heart** is the sovereign of the five **zàng**; by law, it does not receive disease. What receives disease is the **heart’s pericardium**. The **Shou Xin Zhu** is the **hand Jueyin Heart-Pericardium** meridian’s **shu** point. The **Shou Xin Zhu** point is **earth**; the **heart’s fire** is its child—thus, draining its **shu** point is draining its child. This is **welcoming and taking**.

Referring back to the previous text: Supplement the **Shou Xin Zhu** **jing** (well) point. The **heart’s fire** is the child of **wood**; **wood** is the **mother** of **fire**. Now, supplementing the **well** of the **Shou Xin Zhu** is supplementing its mother. This is called **following and supplementing**.

What is meant by **fullness** and **emptiness**? This refers to **tao (牢)** and **ru (濡)**.
**Ru** is **emptiness**; **tao** is **fullness**.
When *qi* arrives **tao** and **full**, it is **success**; when **ru** and **empty**, it is **failure**—thus, *"either success or failure."*

Before performing **supplementation or drainage**, first **palpate** the **zàng**’s **shu** points and the points to be needled. If the *qi* arrives **tao** and **full**, it may be drained; if **ru** and **empty**, it may be supplemented. If one holds the needle and cannot **discern** its **tao** or **ru**, then it is *"either success or failure."*

The *Ba Shi Nan* (Eighty Difficulties) asks:
The classics say: *"There are those who see [the needle] as entering, those who see the needle as entering, and those who see [the needle] as exiting."* What does this mean? How is *"seeing the needle as exiting"*?

Thus:
What is meant by *"seeing as entering"* is that the left hand **observes** the *qi* arriving before inserting the needle. When needling a person, first use the left hand to **palpate** the *qi* in the **an** (安) region. When the *qi* arrives, then insert the needle. The needle enters the point. When the *qi* is exhausted, withdraw the needle. **Palpate** until the *qi* is exhausted before withdrawing the needle—this is not the method of **welcoming, following, supplementation, or drainage**. This is called *"seeing as entering, seeing as exiting."*

Summarizing the previous text.

The **Eighty-One Difficulties** states: *"The Classics speak of ‘solid-solid, hollow-hollow’ [needling], and of ‘draining the deficient while supplementing the excessive.’"* Refer to the annotations on the **Twelfth Difficulty**.

Is this regarding the *cùnkǒu* (寸口) pulse? Ask: *"What is the pulse like?"* Is this regarding the patient’s inherent deficiency or excess? Ask: *"Does the disease itself have deficiency or excess?"*

How does one apply the method of **draining** and **supplementing**?

Suppose the **liver** is solid (real) while the **lungs** are hollow (deficient). The liver is **wood**, the lungs are **metal**. Metal and wood should **mutually balance**—metal should **subdue** wood. See the **Seventy-Fifth Difficulty** for details.

Suppose the lungs are solid. For instance, if the **lung-qi** is strong and excessive, one would recognize that the liver is deficient with **scant and faint** *qi*.

If the liver’s *qi* is **weak and deficient**, **fine and sparse**, yet the practitioner **needles without supplementing the liver** and instead **further strengthens the lungs**, this is the error of **draining the deficient while supplementing the excessive**.

Thus, the saying *"solid-solid, hollow-hollow"* and *"draining the deficient while supplementing the excessive"* is the **harm** caused by **mediocre practitioners**.

This is the **harm** of mediocre practitioners, whereby they apply *"solid-solid, hollow-hollow"* and *"drain the deficient while supplementing the excessive."*

**Volume One of the *Yellow Emperor’s Eighty-One Difficulties* Compiled and Annotated by Lu Guo and Qin Yue Ren, with Commentary by Li Xi and Fan Zi from Linchuan**

**Chapter 1: The *Pulse Ox’s* Diagnostic Observations**
**Difficulty 1:** The first verse expounds upon the difficulty and inquires: All twelve meridians possess the **Pulse Ox** (*Tunxi*). The term *jing* (經) means pathway, constancy—the constant pathways through which **meridian-qi** flows. The three **Yin** and three **Yang** meridians of the hand, and the three **Yin** and three **Yang** meridians of the foot:

- The **Heart**, the hand **Lesser Yin** meridian;
- The **Small Intestine**, the hand **Greater Yang** meridian;
- The **Liver**, the foot **Jue Yin** meridian;
- The **Gallbladder**, the foot **Lesser Yang** meridian;
- The **Kidneys**, the foot **Lesser Yin** meridian;
- The **Bladder**, the foot **Greater Yang** meridian;
- The **Lungs**, the hand **Greater Yin** meridian;
- The **Large Intestine**, the hand **Yangming** meridian;
- The **Spleen**, the foot **Greater Yin** meridian;
- The **Stomach**, the foot **Yangming** meridian;
- The **Pericardium**, the hand **Jue Yin** meridian;
- The **Triple Burner**, the hand **Lesser Yang** meridian.

Among the twelve meridians above, all possess the **Pulse Ox** (*Tunxi*) with manifest movement. Yet only the **Cun Kou** (寸口) is taken to determine the laws of life, death, auspice, and inauspice for the five **Zang** (藏) and six **Fu** (府). What does this mean?

At a distance of one *cun* (寸) from the **Yu Ji** (魚際) bone, it is named **Cun Kou** (寸口). The **Liver**, **Heart**, **Spleen**, **Lungs**, and **Kidneys** are the five **Zang** (藏); the **Gallbladder**, **Stomach**, **Large Intestine**, **Small Intestine**, **Bladder**, and **Triple Burner** are the six **Fu** (府). Yet only the **Cun Kou** (寸口) of one meridian is used to judge whether the central **Zang** (藏) and **Fu** (府) are in life or death, auspice or inauspice. How is this explained?

The **Cun Kou** (寸口) is the grand confluence of the meridians, where the **hand Greater Yin** meridian pulses. This refers specifically to the **Cun Kou** (寸口) of the right hand, the **hand Greater Yin** meridian, which converges at **Da Yuan** (大渊). **Da Yuan** (大渊) is the name of an acupoint, a critical junction where the twelve meridians meet. It is the place where the **hand Greater Yin** meridian’s **Pulse Ox** (*Tunxi*) manifests.

When a person exhales, the **Pulse Ox** (*Tunxi*) travels three *cun* (寸). Exhalation corresponds to **Yang** emergence; between one exhalation, the **Greater Yang**, **Lesser Yang**, and **Yangming** meridians advance, totaling three *cun*. When a person inhales, the **Pulse Ox** (*Tunxi*) travels three *cun*. Inhalation follows **Yin** entry; between one inhalation, the **Greater Yin**, **Lesser Yin**, and **Jue Yin** meridians advance, totaling three *cun*. With exhalation and inhalation settled, the **Pulse Ox** (*Tunxi*) travels six *cun*. The rise and fall of **Heaven** and **Earth**’s **Yin** and **Yang**, like the waxing and waning of the sun and moon, are thus determined. The **Pulse Ox** (*Tunxi*) travels twenty-five *cun* during exhalation and twenty-five *cun* during inhalation, completing fifty degrees in one cycle around the body. The **Cun Kou** (寸口) is the starting and ending point of the five **Zang** (藏) and six **Fu** (府), hence the law is taken from the **Cun Kou** (寸口).

The **Cun Kou** (寸口) begins at the right hand’s **Lung** meridian. From the **Lungs** and **Large Intestine**, it proceeds to the **Stomach** and **Spleen**; from the **Spleen**, it moves to the **Heart** and **Small Intestine**; from the **Small Intestine**, it advances to the **Bladder** and **Kidneys**; from the **Kidneys**, it travels to the **Pericardium** and **Triple Burner**; and from the **Triple Burner**, it returns to the **Gallbladder** and **Liver**, where the cycle ends—and then begins anew at the **Lungs**. The **Nutritive Qi** (*Honor-Wei*) and **Defensive Qi** (*Wei*) circulate twenty-five degrees along **Yang** and twenty-five degrees along **Yin**, completing one cycle. **Nutritive Qi** (*Honor-Wei*) belongs to **blood** and **Yin**, circulating within the meridians; **Defensive Qi** (*Wei*) belongs to **qi** and **Yang**, circulating outside the meridians. The **qi** and **blood** are awake while traversing the body and rest within the **Zang** (藏), ceaselessly cycling day and night without pause. In two hundred seventy breaths, the **Pulse Ox** (*Tunxi*) travels sixteen *zhang* two *chi* (丈二尺), corresponding to two *ke* (刻) of the **water clock** (*Lou Shu*). In thirteen thousand five hundred breaths, the **Pulse Ox** (*Tunxi*) travels eight hundred ten *zhang* (丈), corresponding to one hundred *ke* (刻) of the **water clock** (*Lou Shu*). Twenty-five degrees of **Yang** and twenty-five degrees of **Yin** make up the measure of the **water clock** (*Lou Shu*). One cycle corresponds to one full day and night. Thus, fifty cycles converge again at the **hand Greater Yin** meridian.

chunks.original_text: 故诊视法度，叉取於寸口，以断死生吉凶也。 二难曰： 第二首诂难而问日。 脉有尺寸，何谓也？ 脉有尺部，有寸部，其说如何。 然：尺寸者，脉之大要会也。 寸为阳部，乃阳要会之处； 尺为阴部，乃阴要会之处。 此豚之大要会，实在尺寸。 从关至尺是尺内，阴之所治也； 从关至鱼际是寸口内，阳之所治也。 关部为阴阳之关津，关前为阳，关后为阴。 从关至尺泽穴，当一尺，是尺部内，阴之所治也。 尺部脉见一寸耳，而言尺者，是其根也。 从关至鱼际骨是寸切内，阳之所治也。 寸口长一寸，而豚见九分也。 故分寸为尺，分尺为寸。 互以尺寸分之，便知寸口尺部。 故阴得尺内一寸，阳得寸内九分。 阴数耦，地数十，故阴部得尺内一寸。 阳数奇，天数九，故阳部得寸内九分。 故尺寸终始，一寸九分，故日尺寸也。 阳气生於尺而动於寸，阴气生於寸而动於尺，是以法阳气始生於立春，上至芒种之节，其数九，三阳王於前，法寸内九分而浮。 夏至之节，其气下行，至立冬而终，其数十，三阴王於后，法尺内一寸而沉。 此阳中阴阳始终也。 阴气复从立秋而生，下冬至之节，其数十。 冬至之后，随少阳上行，至立夏之节，其数九。 此阴中阴阳始终也。 尺寸各有终始，一寸九分，故日尺寸。 三难曰： 同前。

Thus, the diagnostic method of **pulse examination** relies on the **Cun Kou** (寸口), by which one discerns life and death, fortune and misfortune.

**Second Difficulty:** The second inquiry elaborates and asks: What are the **Cun** and **Chi** (尺寸) of the pulse?

The pulse has a **Chi** (尺) section and a **Cun** (寸) section—how does this distinction arise?

Indeed, the **Cun** and **Chi** are the pulse’s great confluence. The **Cun** belongs to the **Yang** region, marking the convergence of **Yang**’s essence; the **Chi** belongs to the **Yin** region, marking the convergence of **Yin**’s essence. This is where the **Pulse Ox** (*Tunxi*) gathers most profoundly.

From the **Guan** (关) to the **Chi** is the **Chi** region, governed by **Yin**; from the **Guan** to the **Yu Ji** (鱼际) is the **Cun Kou** region, governed by **Yang**. The **Guan** is the pass between **Yin** and **Yang**—before the **Guan** is **Yang**, after the **Guan** is **Yin**.

From the **Guan** to the **Chi Ze** (尺泽) acupoint, spanning one **Chi**, lies within the **Chi** region, governed by **Yin**. Though the **Chi** region’s pulse appears only one **Cun** long, it is called **Chi** because it is the root.

From the **Guan** to the **Yu Ji** bone is the **Cun** region, governed by **Yang**. The **Cun Kou** measures one **Cun**, yet the **Pulse Ox** manifests nine **Fen** (分).

Thus, **Chi** is divided into **Cun**, and **Cun** is divided into **Fen**. By cross-referencing **Chi** and **Cun**, one discerns the **Cun Kou** and **Chi** regions. Hence, **Yin** occupies one **Cun** within the **Chi** region, while **Yang** occupies nine **Fen** within the **Cun** region.

**Yin** is paired (even), Earth’s number is ten, so **Yin** occupies one **Cun** within the **Chi** region. **Yang** is odd, Heaven’s number is nine, so **Yang** occupies nine **Fen** within the **Cun** region.

Thus, the **Chi** and **Cun** mark the beginning and end—one **Cun** and nine **Fen**—hence the term **Chi Cun** (尺寸).

**Yang qi** originates in the **Chi** and moves to the **Cun**; **Yin qi** originates in the **Cun** and moves to the **Chi**. Therefore, the law states that **Yang qi** first arises at **Lì Chun** (立春), ascending to the **Mang Zhong** (芒种) node—its count is nine, with the Three **Yangs** reigning ahead, corresponding to the nine **Fen** within the **Cun** as floating.

At the **Xia Zhi** (夏至) node, its **qi** descends, reaching **Lì Dong** (立冬) to conclude—its count is ten, with the Three **Yins** reigning behind, corresponding to one **Cun** within the **Chi** as deep.

This is the **Yin** within **Yang**’s beginning and end.

**Yin qi** again arises from **Lì Qiū** (立秋), descending to the **Dong Zhi** (冬至) node—its count is ten. After **Dong Zhi**, it follows the **Shao Yang** upward, reaching the **Lì Xia** (立夏) node—its count is nine.

This is the **Yang** within **Yin**’s beginning and end.

The **Chi** and **Cun** each mark their own beginning and end—one **Cun** and nine **Fen**—hence the term **Chi Cun**.

chunks.original_text: 脉有太过。 脉息有太过其部位。 有不及。 有不及其部位。 有阴阳相乘。 有阴豚乘阳部，有阳脉乘阴部。 有覆。 覆行之脉，从关至尺泽。 有溢。 盈溢之豚，从寸口盈溢，上至鱼际骨。 有关有格。 关，闭也； 格，拒也。 阴气太盛，阳气不得营，故日鬲。 阳气太盛，阴气不得营，故日关。 阴阳俱盛，不得相营，故曰关鬲。 何谓也？ 其说如何。 然：关之前者，阳之动也。 阳气生於尺而动於寸，关前名寸口，是阳气动作之处。 脉当#5九分而浮。 阳数奇，其数九，阳豚浮，故寸口豚九分而浮。 过者，法日太过。 过者，脉过九分，出一寸。 又寸豚本浮，又加实大，为太过脉。 减者，法曰不及。 喊者，脉不及九分，至八分、七分、六分也。 又阳豚本浮，轻手而按之，损至而小为不及。 遂上鱼为溢。 上鱼际骨，为脉盈溢，浮而实大。 上鱼为阳溢，浮而损小者，阳不及也。 阳不及则阴入乘之，为阴溢。 为外关内格。 外关者，内豚不得出，日不及，亦日阴乘豚。 内格者，外豚不得入，日太过，日溢脉。 此阴乘之脉也。 此是阴脉乘於阳部之脉。 关以后者，阴之动也。 阴生於寸而动於尺，关后为尺部，是阴气动作之处。 脉当#6一寸而沉。 阴数耦，其数十，阴豚况，故尺脉当一寸而沉。 过者，法日太过。 过者，脉出过一寸至一寸二分、三分、四分、五分也。 尺脉本况，重手按之，又加实大，为阴太过。 臧者，法日不及。 喊者，脉不满一寸，止见八分、七分、六分。 又阴脉本沉而濡，重手按之，损至而小，为阴不及。 遂入尺为覆。 覆行之脉，从关至尺泽穴，脉见一寸，其於伏行不见也，沉之损小，是阴不及，阴不及则阳入乘之，名日阳覆，又内关外格。 为内关外格。 内关者，外脉不得入，为阴不及，则阳入乘之。 外格者，内脉不得出，为阴太过，又为阳覆。 此阳乘之脉。 此是阴脉乘於阳部之脉。 故曰覆溢。 诸阴不足，阳入乘之，为覆。 诸阳不足，阴入乘之，为溢。 是其真藏之脉，人不病而死也。 真藏咏是独见本藏脉者，皆死，偏阳偏阴亦死。 四难曰： 脉有阴阳之法，何谓也？ 脉有阴有阳，其法度如何。 然：呼出心与肺。 心肺在鬲上，藏中之阳，呼者因阳出，故呼之气出於心肺。 吸入肾与肝。 肝肾在鬲下，藏中之阴，吸者随阴入，故吸之气入於肾肝。 呼吸之问，脾受谷味也，其脉在中。 脾者中州，上有心肺，下有肾肝，故呼吸中问乃脾也。 脾胃仓凛之官，主受五谷。 谷，谷也。 谷，空也。 脾受谷味，以为呼吸之本。 浮者阳也。 浮脉循皮肤血咏之问，在肌肉之上，此为阳脉。 沉者阴也。 沉脉循行，帖筋辅骨，此为阴脉。 故曰阴阳也。 总言浮阳况阴之脉。 心肺俱浮，何以别之？ 心象火，於外独明，故心脉浮。 肺象金，於位独高，故肺脉浮。 二者皆浮，何以辫别。 浮而大散者，心也。 浮而大散，方是心脉。 大者，是藏脉； 散者，是府脉。 浮而短涩者，肺也。 不及本位日短，细而迟，往来难，时一止，日涩。 浮而短涩，方是肺脉，短者是藏，涩者是府。 肝肾俱沉，何以别之？ 肝肾在鬲下，故脉皆沉，何所有别。 然：牢而长者，肝也。 肝属木，肝木生於地，牢义可知。 枝叶长於天，长义出此。 牢者是藏，长者是府。
chunks.translated_text:
The pulse has **excess** (太過). The pulse beats in **excess** at their designated positions. There is **deficiency**. There is **deficiency** at their designated positions. There is **Yin-Yang counteraction**. There is **Yin-qi counteracting the Yang pulse**, and there is **Yang pulse counteracting the Yin position**.

There is **covering** (覆). The **covering pulse** travels from the *Guan* (關) to the *Chi Ze* (尺澤). There is **overflow** (溢). The **overflowing pulse** swells at the *Cun Kou* (寸口), extending upward to the *Yu Ji* (魚際) bone.

There is **closure** (關) and **repulsion** (格). *Guan* means **closure**; *ge* means **repulsion**. When **Yin-qi is excessive**, **Yang-qi cannot circulate**, hence it is called **closure** (鬲). When **Yang-qi is excessive**, **Yin-qi cannot circulate**, hence it is called **closure** (關). When both **Yin and Yang are excessive**, neither can circulate properly, hence it is called **closure and repulsion** (關鬲). What does this mean? How is this explained?

Before the *Guan* (關), it is the movement of **Yang**. **Yang-qi** originates at the *Chi* (尺) and moves to the *Cun* (寸). The region before the *Guan* is called *Cun Kou* (寸口), where **Yang-qi** moves and acts. The pulse should be **nine *fen* (分) and floating**. Since **Yang** is an odd number, its count is nine, and the **Yang pulse is floating**, hence the *Cun Kou* pulse is **nine *fen* and floating**.

If it **exceeds**, it is called **excess** (太過). If it exceeds nine *fen*, it extends to **one *cun* (寸)**. The *Cun* pulse is originally floating, and if it becomes additionally **full and large**, it is an **excess pulse**. If it **lacks**, it is called **deficiency** (不及). If it does not reach nine *fen*, it may be **eight, seven, or six *fen***. The *Cun* pulse is originally floating; if pressed lightly, it diminishes and becomes small, which is **deficiency**. If it overflows upward to *Yu Ji* (魚際), it is called **overflow** (溢). The pulse swells at *Yu Ji* bone, **floating and large**, which is **Yang overflow**. If it is floating yet diminished and small, it is **Yang deficiency**. When **Yang is deficient**, **Yin invades and counteracts**, resulting in **Yin overflow**. This is called **external closure and internal repulsion** (外關內格). **External closure** means the internal pulse cannot emerge, which is **deficiency**, also called **Yin counteracting the pulse**. **Internal repulsion** means the external pulse cannot enter, which is **excess**, also called **overflowing pulse**. This is the pulse of **Yin counteraction**, the pulse where **Yin-qi counteracts the Yang position**.

After the *Guan* (關), it is the movement of **Yin**. **Yin-qi** originates at the *Cun* (寸) and moves to the *Chi* (尺). The region after the *Guan* is the *Chi* (尺) position, where **Yin-qi** moves and acts. The pulse should be **one *cun* and deep**. Since **Yin** is an even number, its count is ten, and the **Yin pulse is deep**, hence the *Chi* pulse is **one *cun* and deep**.

If it **exceeds**, it is called **excess** (太過). If it exceeds one *cun*, it may extend to **one and two, three, four, or five *fen***. The *Chi* pulse is originally deep; if pressed heavily, it becomes additionally **full and large**, which is **Yin excess**. If it **lacks**, it is called **deficiency** (不及). If it does not reach one *cun*, it may be **eight, seven, or six *fen***. The *Yin* pulse is originally deep and **soft**; if pressed heavily, it diminishes and becomes small, which is **Yin deficiency**. If it descends into the *Chi* as **covering** (覆), the **covering pulse** travels from the *Guan* to the *Chi Ze* (尺澤) acupoint. If the pulse is seen at one *cun*, it is **hidden and not visible**; when pressed deeply, it diminishes and becomes small, which is **Yin deficiency**. When **Yin is deficient**, **Yang invades and counteracts**, called **Yang covering** (陽覆), also **internal closure and external repulsion** (內關外格). **Internal closure** means the external pulse cannot enter, which is **Yin deficiency**, and **Yang invades and counteracts**. **External repulsion** means the internal pulse cannot emerge, which is **Yin excess**, also called **Yang covering**. This is the pulse of **Yang counteraction**, the pulse where **Yang-qi counteracts the Yin position**. Hence it is called **covering and overflow** (覆溢). When all **Yin is insufficient**, **Yang invades and counteracts**, resulting in **covering**. When all **Yang is insufficient**, **Yin invades and counteracts**, resulting in **overflow**. These are the **true藏 pulses**; if seen alone in their original form, they indicate **imminent death**. If seen in **partial Yin or partial Yang**, it also indicates **death**.

**Fourth Difficulty:** What is the **Yin-Yang law of the pulse**? The pulse has **Yin and Yang**; what are their regulations?

When exhaling, the **Heart and Lungs** are engaged. The **Heart and Lungs** are above the *Ge* (鬲), the **Yang** within the **Zang** (藏). Exhalation follows **Yang**, so the exhaled breath emerges from the **Heart and Lungs**. When inhaling, the **Kidneys and Liver** are engaged. The **Liver and Kidneys** are below the *Ge* (鬲), the **Yin** within the **Zang** (藏). Inhalation follows **Yin**, so the inhaled breath enters the **Kidneys and Liver**. Between exhalation and inhalation, the **Spleen** receives the flavors of grains. The pulse lies in the middle. The **Spleen** is the central state; above it are the **Heart and Lungs**, below it are the **Kidneys and Liver**, so the pulse between exhalation and inhalation belongs to the **Spleen**. The **Spleen and Stomach** are the **granaries and storehouses**, responsible for receiving the **Five Grains**. *Gu* (谷) means **grain**; *ku* (空) means **empty**. The **Spleen** receives the flavors of grains as the foundation for exhalation and inhalation.

The **floating pulse** is **Yang**. The floating pulse travels between the **skin and blood vessels**, above the **muscles**, which is the **Yang pulse**. The **deep pulse** is **Yin**. The deep pulse travels along the **tendons and beside the bones**, which is the **Yin pulse**. Hence it is called **Yin and Yang**. In summary, the pulse is **floating as Yang and deep as Yin**.

How do we distinguish between the **Heart and Lungs**, both of which are floating? The **Heart** is like **fire**, externally luminous, so the **Heart pulse is floating**. The **Lung** is like **metal**, positioned highest, so the **Lung pulse is floating**. How do we differentiate between the two, both being floating? If it is **floating, large, and dispersed**, it is the **Heart**. A **large pulse** is the **Zang pulse**; a **dispersed pulse** is the **Fu pulse**. If it is **floating, short, and hesitant**, it is the **Lung**. If it does not reach its proper position, it is **short**; if it is **fine and slow**, with **difficult movement** and **occasional cessation**, it is **hesitant**. A **floating, short, and hesitant pulse** is the **Lung pulse**—**short** refers to the **Zang**, and **hesitant** refers to the **Fu**.

How do we distinguish between the **Liver and Kidneys**, both of which are deep? The **Liver and Kidneys** are below the *Ge* (鬲), so their pulses are all deep. How can they be differentiated?

If it is **firm and long**, it is the **Liver**. The **Liver** belongs to **Wood**; **Wood** grows from the earth, hence its **firmness** is understood. Its **branches and leaves** extend to the sky, hence its **length**. **Firm** refers to the **Zang pulse**; **long** refers to the **Fu pulse**.

chunks.original_text: 按之濡，举指来实者，肾也。 肾属水，其性濡，水性外柔，按之乃濡，水性内刚，举之乃实。 濡者是藏，实者是府。 脾者中州。 脾属土，位居中央。 州者，州县之义。 中州者，中国之义。 故其脉在中。 上有心肺，下有肝肾，而脾脉在於其中。 是阴阳之法也。 心为阳藏，位处上焦，以阳居阳，故为阳中之阳。 肺为阴藏，位处上焦，以阴居阳，故为阴中之阳。 肾为阴藏，位处下焦，以阴居阴，故为阴中之阴。 肝为阳藏，位处中焦，以阳居阴，故为阴中之阳。 脾为阴藏，位居中焦，以太阴居阴，为阴中之至阴。 脉有一阴一阳，一阴二阳，一阴三阳； 有一阳一阴，一阳二阴，一阳三阴。 有脉或一阴一阳，或一阴二阳，或一阴三阳； 有脉或一阳一阴，或一阳二阴，或一阳三阴。 如此之言。 如此言阴阳脉。

chunks.original_text: 寸口有六脉俱动耶？ 问寸口之中，有六脉皆形动耶。 然：言此#7 者。 言此六脉。 非有六脉俱动也。 非是六脉！ 俱动於寸口。 谓脉来浮、沉、长、短、滑、涩也。 引三阴三阳脉，以应六气，浮、滑、长，三阳脉； 沉、短、涩，三阴脉。 浮者阳也。 浮是少阳脉。 滑者阳也。 滑是阳明豚。 长者阳也。 长是太阳脉。 沉者阴也。 沉是少阴脉。 短者阴也。 短是厥阴豚。 涩者阴也。 涩是太阴豚。 所谓一阴一阳者，谓脉来沉而滑也。 一阴者，是况脉也。 一阳者，是滑脉也。 若脉见於左手尺部，此是肾与膀胱，藏府表裹顺也。 若在左手寸口，即为病豚逆也。 一阴二阳者，谓脉来沉滑而长也。 一阴者，脉况也。 二阳者，脉滑而长也。 此脉见於阴部，是阳下乘於阴部。 一阴三阳者，谓脉来浮滑而长，时一沉也。 一阴者，脉沉也。 三阳者，脉浮滑长也。 尺中已浮滑而长，又时一沉，此是阳中伏阴也。 所言一阳一阴者，谓脉来浮而涩也。 一阳者，脉浮也。 一阴者，豚涩也。 浮涩者肺脉，当见右手寸口，是本部之阴阳顺也。 若在左关，即病为逆也。 一阳二阴者＇谓脉来长而沉涩也。 一阳者，豚长也。 二阴者，脉沉涩也。 脉居阳部，而反阴脉现者，此是血气俱虚，为阴乘阳者也。 一阳三阴者，谓脉来沉涩而短，时一浮也。 一阳者，脉浮也。 三阴者，脉况涩短也。 寸部已沉涩而短，又时时浮者，此阴中伏阳也。 各以其经所在，名病逆顺也。 各以十二经所在，观春夏秋冬六豚之变，则知病之逆顺也。 五难曰： 脉有轻重，何谓也？ 诊脉有轻有重，以等阴阳高下，其说如何。 然：初持脉。 先看肺豚，举一例以为式。 假令初诊右手寸口肺脉。 如三菽之重，与皮毛相得者，肺部也。 菽者，豆也。 肺主皮毛，如三豆之重，在皮毛之问，是肺脉。 几诊肺豚，要轻手以按之。 如六菽之重，与血脉相得者，心部也。 心主血脉，次於肺，如六豆之重。 几诊心脉，要略重手以按之。 如九菽之重，与肌肉相得者，脾部也。 脾主肌肉，故次心，如九豆之重。 几诊脾脉，要不轻不重手以按之。 如十二菽之重，与筋卑#8者，肝部也。 肝主筋，又在脾下，如十二豆之重。 几诊肝脉，略重手按之。 按之至骨，举指来疾者，肾部也。 肾主骨，其脉况，要重下手按至於骨。 举起手指，脉来急疾乃是肾脉也。 故日轻重也。 心肺在鬲上，藏中之阳，阳浮於上，宜轻按之。 肝肾在鬲下，藏中之阴，阴沉於下，宜重按之。 六难曰： 脉有阳盛阴虚，阴盛阳虚，何谓也？ 有阳脉盛实而阴脉虚损，有阴豚盛实而阳脉虚损，其说如何。 然：浮之损小。 浮为阳脉，浮而损小，为阳脉之虚。 阳脉是寸口，本浮而实，今轻手浮而得之，更损灭#9而小，故日阳虚不足。 沉之实大。 沉为阴脉，沉而实大，为阴脉之盛。 阴脉是尺部，本沉而濡，重手按之，及更实大，是阴盛太过。 故曰阴盛阳虚。 故断之日阴盛阳虚之脉。 沉之损小。 沉为阴脉，沉而损小为阴脉虚。 阴豚本沉，重手按之，更损至而小，是阴虚不足也。 浮之实大。 浮为阳脉，浮而实大，是阳脉之盛。 阳脉本浮，轻手按之，更加实大，是阳盛太过也。 故日阳盛阴虚。 故断之日阳盛阴虚之脉。 是阴阳虚实之意。 又总言阴阳虚实之意。

At the *cùnkǒu* [寸口], are there six pulses all moving together?
When inquiring within the *cùnkǒu*, are there six pulses all visibly manifesting?
Indeed: speaking of this—
Speaking of these six pulses.
It is not that six pulses move together.
It is not that these six pulses
all move at the *cùnkǒu*.
Rather, it refers to the pulse arriving as **floating, deep, long, short, smooth, or rough**.

Drawing upon the three *yin* and three *yang* pulses to correspond with the six *qi* [六气]:
Floating, smooth, and long belong to the three *yang* pulses;
Deep, short, and rough belong to the three *yin* pulses.

Floating is *yang*.
Floating is the *Shao Yang* pulse.
Smooth is *yang*.
Smooth is the *Yang Ming* pulse.
Long is *yang*.
Long is the *Tai Yang* pulse.
Deep is *yin*.
Deep is the *Shao Yin* pulse.
Short is *yin*.
Short is the *Jue Yin* pulse.
Rough is *yin*.
Rough is the *Tai Yin* pulse.

What is called **"one *yin* and one *yang**"** refers to the pulse arriving as deep yet smooth.
One *yin* is the **rough pulse**.
One *yang* is the **smooth pulse**.
If the pulse appears at the left hand’s *chi* [尺] department, this is the Kidney and Bladder—**the *Zang-Fu* [藏府] exterior-interior harmony in order**.
If it appears at the left *cùnkǒu*, then it is **a disorder of inversion**.

**"One *yin* and two *yang*"** refers to the pulse arriving as deep, smooth, and long.
One *yin* is the **rough pulse**.
Two *yang* are the **smooth and long pulses**.
This pulse appearing in the *yin* department is **the *yang* descending to dominate the *yin* department**.

**"One *yin* and three *yang*"** refers to the pulse arriving as floating, smooth, and long, yet occasionally deep.
One *yin* is the **deep pulse**.
Three *yang* are the **floating, smooth, and long pulses**.
Already at the *chi* department, it is floating, smooth, and long, yet again occasionally deep—this is **a hidden *yin* within *yang***.

What is called **"one *yang* and one *yin*"** refers to the pulse arriving as floating yet rough.
One *yang* is the **floating pulse**.
One *yin* is the **rough pulse**.
A floating and rough pulse belongs to the Lung—**it should appear at the right hand’s *cùnkǒu*, marking the original department’s *yin-yang* harmony in order**.
If it appears at the *guan* [关], then it is **a disorder of inversion**.

**"One *yang* and two *yin*"** refers to the pulse arriving as long yet deep and rough.
One *yang* is the **long pulse**.
Two *yin* are the **deep and rough pulses**.
The pulse residing in the *yang* department yet revealing *yin* characteristics—this is **blood and *qi* both depleted, *yin* dominating *yang***.

**"One *yang* and three *yin*"** refers to the pulse arriving as deep, rough, and short, yet occasionally floating.
One *yang* is the **floating pulse**.
Three *yin* are the **rough, deep, and short pulses**.
Already at the *cùnkǒu* department, it is deep, rough, and short, yet again occasionally floating—this is **a hidden *yang* within *yin***.

Each is named according to the channel’s location—**whether the disease is inverted or orderly**.
Each is observed through the twelve channels’ locations, examining the six *qi*’s [六气] changes in spring, summer, autumn, and winter, thus knowing whether the disease is inverted or orderly.

---
The **Five Difficulties** say:
*The pulse has lightness and heaviness—what does this mean?*
When diagnosing the pulse, there is lightness and heaviness—how does this correspond to *yin-yang* elevation and depression? Indeed:
At first, when holding the pulse,
First observe the Lung pulse as an example.
Suppose when initially diagnosing the right hand’s *cùnkǒu* Lung pulse,
If it weighs like **three mung beans** and aligns with the skin and fur—this is the Lung department.
*Mung beans* are beans.
The Lung governs skin and fur; like three beans in weight, between the skin and fur—this is the Lung pulse.
When diagnosing the Lung pulse, one must use a **light hand** to press.
If it weighs like **six mung beans** and aligns with the blood vessels—this is the Heart department.
The Heart governs blood vessels; next to the Lung, like six beans in weight.
When diagnosing the Heart pulse, one must use a **moderately heavy hand** to press.
If it weighs like **nine mung beans** and aligns with the muscles—this is the Spleen department.
The Spleen governs muscles; thus, after the Heart, like nine beans in weight.
When diagnosing the Spleen pulse, one must use a **neither-light-nor-heavy hand** to press.
If it weighs like **twelve mung beans** and aligns with the tendons and bones—this is the Liver department.
The Liver governs tendons; again below the Spleen, like twelve beans in weight.
When diagnosing the Liver pulse, one must use a **moderately heavy hand** to press.
Pressing until the bone, then lifting the finger swiftly—this is the Kidney department.
The Kidney governs bones; its pulse is rough, requiring a **heavy downward hand** to press until the bone.
Lifting the hand, if the pulse arrives swiftly and urgently—this is the Kidney pulse.
Thus it is said: **lightness and heaviness**.
The Heart and Lung are above the *ge* [鬲], the *Zang*’s *yang*—*yang* floats above, so it should be pressed lightly.
The Liver and Kidney are below the *ge*, the *Zang*’s *yin*—*yin* sinks below, so it should be pressed heavily.

---
The **Sixth Difficulty** says:
*The pulse has *yang* excess and *yin* deficiency, *yin* excess and *yang* deficiency—what does this mean?*
There are cases where the *yang* pulse is excessive and full while the *yin* pulse is depleted, and cases where the *yin* pulse is excessive and full while the *yang* pulse is depleted—how does this manifest? Indeed:
When floating, it is diminished.
Floating is the *yang* pulse; if floating yet diminished, it is *yang* deficiency.
The *yang* pulse is at *cùnkǒu*, originally floating and full; now, with a light hand, it is obtained as floating, yet further diminished and small—thus it is said: **the *yang* is deficient and insufficient**.
When deep, it is full and large.
Deep is the *yin* pulse; if deep yet full and large, it is *yin* excess.
The *yin* pulse is at the *chi* department, originally deep and slack; pressing heavily, it becomes even more full and large—this is **excessive *yin***.
Thus it is said: **the *yin* is excessive and the *yang* is deficient**.
Thus it is diagnosed as **the pulse of *yin* excess and *yang* deficiency**.
When deep, it is diminished.
Deep is the *yin* pulse; if deep yet diminished, it is *yin* deficiency.
The *yin* pulse is originally deep; pressing heavily, it becomes even more diminished and small—this is **the *yin* being deficient and insufficient**.
When floating, it is full and large.
Floating is the *yang* pulse; if floating yet full and large, it is *yang* excess.
The *yang* pulse is originally floating; pressing lightly, it becomes even more full and large—this is **excessive *yang***.
Thus it is said: **the *yang* is excessive and the *yin* is deficient**.
Thus it is diagnosed as **the pulse of *yang* excess and *yin* deficiency**.
This is the meaning of *yin-yang* deficiency and excess.

The **Seven Difficulties** state:

The *Classic* says that when *Shao-Yang* arrives, its pulse is alternately large and small, alternately short and long. *Shao-Yang* reigns in the first and second months; its *qi* is still weak and small, so its pulse advances and retreats irregularly, with no fixed size or length. When *Yang-Ming* arrives, the pulse is floating, large, and short. *Yang-Ming* reigns in the third and fourth months; its *qi* has just begun to sprout but is not yet flourishing, so the pulse comes floating, large, and short. When *Tai-Yang* arrives, the pulse is surging and long. *Tai-Yang* reigns in the fifth and sixth months; its *qi* is excessively strong, so the pulse comes surging, large, and long. When *Tai-Yin* arrives, the pulse is taut, large, and long. *Tai-Yin* reigns in the seventh and eighth months; it inherits the residual *yang* of summer, and *yin* *qi* is not yet strong, so the pulse comes taut, large, and long. When *Shao-Yin* arrives, the pulse is taut, fine, and faint. *Shao-Yin* reigns in the ninth and tenth months; *yang* *qi* declines while *yin* *qi* flourishes, so the pulse is taut, fine, and faint. When *Jue-Yin* arrives, the pulse is deep, short, and firm. *Jue-Yin* reigns in the eleventh and twelfth months; *yin* *qi* is strong, so the pulse comes deep, short, and firm.

Are these six pulses normal? — *Question:* These six pulses—do they belong to the harmonious pulse?
Or are they disease pulses? — *Question:* Do they belong to disease pulses?
*Answer:* They are all **Reigning Pulses**.

Which months do their *qi* reign for how many days?
— *Question:* For the three *yin* and three *yang*, which months do their *qi* reign, and for how many days?

*Answer:* After the Winter Solstice, the first *Jia-Zi* marks *Shao-Yang* reigning. The heavens complete a year through six cycles of sixty days. From the Winter Solstice onward, the first *Jia-Zi* marks the beginning of the new year’s *qi*—sometimes occurring at the start of *Xiao-Han*, sometimes after *Da-Han*. Thus, *Shao-Yang* *qi* has not yet emerged from the *yin* phase, so the pulse is alternately large, small, short, and long.

Next, the second *Jia-Zi* marks *Yang-Ming* reigning—this is the second cycle of *qi*; its warmth begins, but its *qi* is not yet strong, so the pulse comes floating, large, and short.

Next, the third *Jia-Zi* marks *Tai-Yang* reigning—this is the third cycle of *qi*; it is the peak of *yang*, so the pulse comes surging, large, and long.

Next, the fourth *Jia-Zi* marks *Tai-Yin* reigning—this is the fourth cycle of *qi*; it is the phase of summer heat and dampness, and autumn *qi* begins, riding upon the residual *yang* of summer, so the pulse comes taut, large, and long.

Next, the fifth *Jia-Zi* marks *Shao-Yin* reigning—this is the fifth cycle of *qi*; it is the phase of crisp clarity, so the pulse is taut, fine, and faint.

Next, the sixth *Jia-Zi* marks *Jue-Yin* reigning—this is the terminal cycle of *qi*; it is the phase of extreme *yin*, when water congeals like stone, so the pulse is deep, short, and firm.

Each reigns for sixty days. The three *yin* and three *yang* each reign for sixty days—six cycles of sixty days make three hundred sixty days, completing one year. Within a year, the three hundred sixty days are divided into four seasons.

This is the general principle of the reigning periods of the three *yin* and three *yang* according to the *Liu-Jia* cycles.

chunks.original_text: 皆系於生气之原。 十二经皆关系於肾。 肾者，发生脉气根原。 所谓生气之原者，谓十二经之根本也。 肾者，生气之原，为十二经脉之根本也。 谓肾问动气也。 两肾之闲动气，乃人所受父母之原气。 又气冲之脉，起於两肾之间。 此五脏六腑之本，十二经脉之根。 五脏六腑分为十二经，实以肾为根本。 呼吸之门。 肾挟任豚上至喉咽，通喘息，为呼吸之门。 三焦之原。 人之三焦，法天地三元之气，以肾为本原。 一名守邪之神。 左为肾，右为命门，有神守於命门，不令邪入志室，邪入志室，人则死矣。 志室，穴名。 故气者，人之根本也。 肾问动气，乃生人性命根本。 根绝则茎叶枯矣。 手三阴三阳为枝，足三阴三阳为根，尺部为人之根本，寸口为人之茎叶。 木根绝则木死，人肾绝则人死。 寸口脉平而死者，生气独绝於内也。 肾问动气常隐於内，今寸口传受谷气，虽豚平和，奈人之生气已绝於两肾之问，则十二经无相依十，任寸豚平亦死矣。 九难曰： 何以别知脏腑之病耶？ 五脏六腑疾病，何以辩别知之。 然：数者腑也。 几见数脉，是六腑受病者也。 迟者脏也。 几见迟脉，是五脏受病也。 数则为热。 数是阳脉，主有热证。 迟则为寒。 迟是阴脉，主有寒证。 诸阳为热。 阳气乱则脉数，故诸阳皆为热。 诸阴为寒。 阴气虚则豚迟，故诸阴皆为寒。 故以别知脏腑之病也。 因数迟之脉，可得辩别脏腑之疾病。 十难曰： 一脉为十变者，何谓也？ 一部之中，豚几十变，其说如何。 然； 五邪刚柔相逢之意也。 五邪者，虚邪、实邪、正邪、微邪、贼邪也。 刚柔者，阴阳也。 相逢者，於本位见他豚也。 五脏各有表裹，更相乘之，一豚成十，推此十变之候，乃五行胜复相加也。 邪者，不正之名，非在身王气而外干身为病者，通为之邪也。 假令心脉急甚者，肝邪干心也。 圣人以心部一藏为例。 夏心豚当浮大而散，今反弦急，弦急者，肝豚干心也。 肝是母，心是子，木生火，母乘子，日虚邪。 干，犹乘也。 心脉微急者，胆邪干#1小肠也。 小肠，心之府； 胆，肝之府。 心部微急，乃胆邪干小肠。 心脉大甚者，心邪自干心也。 心咏虽洪大，当以胃气为本，今无胃气，故其脉大甚，此曰正经自病，法日正邪，故云自干。 心脉微大者，小肠邪自干小肠也。 心脉略大，为小肠自病。 心脉缓甚者，脾邪干心也。 缓者脾之脉，今心豚缓甚，是火为母，土为子，子乘母日实邪，脾邪干心之豚。 心脉微缓者，胃邪干小肠也。 於心部轻手得其小缓，是胃邪干乘小肠。 心脉涩甚者，肺邪干心也。 涩者肺之脉，今心部豚涩，金反凌火，法日微邪。 心脉微涩者，大肠邪干小肠也。 心部见小涩脉，是大肠邪干乘小肠。 心脉沉甚者，肾邪干心也。 况者肾之豚，心火炎上，其豚本洪，今反豚况，水来克火，法日贼邪。 心脉微沉者，膀胱#2干小肠也。 於心部重手得其小况，是膀胱邪干乘小肠。 五脏各有刚柔耶。 刚柔者，阴阳也。 五脏各有阴阳，今以心脏为例，余皆仿此。 故令一脉辄变为十也。 一部之中几十次变通，斗部之内，各有五邪，十变共六十首。 十一难曰： 经言脉不满五十动而一止。 一藏五十动，五藏二百五十动，谓之平脉。 今豚之动，不满五十动而一止者，是一藏无气。
